block.p: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.
THEATER

BENJAMIN FRANKLIN MIDDLE SCHOOL The Ridgewood Gilbert and Sullivan Opera Company will present ''The Yeomen of the Guard.'' Saturday at 3 p.m. and 8 p.m.; next Sunday at 3 p.m. Tickets: $15; $12 for older people; $10 youth (ages 12 to 18 years); free for children under 12. 335 North Van Dien Avenue, Ridgewood. (973) 423-0300.

An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.
THEATER

BENJAMIN FRANKLIN MIDDLE SCHOOL The Ridgewood Gilbert and Sullivan Opera Company will present ''The Yeomen of the Guard.'' Saturday at 3 p.m. and 8 p.m.; next Sunday at 3 p.m. Tickets: $15; $12 for older people; $10 youth (ages 12 to 18 years); free for children under 12. 335 North Van Dien Avenue, Ridgewood. (973) 423-0300.
CHESTER THEATER GROUP ''Collected Stories,'' by Donald Marguiles. Fridays and Saturdays at 8 p.m. through June 17. Tickets: $10. Black River Playhouse, Grove Street, Chester. (908) 879-7304.
DOVER LITTLE THEATER Gilbert and Sullivan's ''Pirates of Penzance.'' Through June 24. Fridays and Saturdays at 8 p.m. Tickets: $16. Elliot Street, Dover. (973) 328-9202.

ELMWOOD PLAYHOUSE ''Minnie's Boys,'' Marx Brothers musical. Today at 2:30 p.m.; Friday and Saturday at 8:30 p.m. Tickets: $17; $15 for students and older people. 10 Park Street, Nyack, N.Y. (914) 353-1313.

GEORGE STREET PLAYHOUSE The Next Stage Festival. Through next Sunday in the New Stage Theater. ''Waiting for Tadashi.'' Today at 7 p.m. ''Second Chance.'' Friday and Saturday at 8 p.m.; next Sunday at 7 p.m. Tickets: $10. ''Looking East,'' performed by Randy James Dance Works. Friday and Saturday at 8 p.m.; next Sunday at 3 p.m. Tickets: $15; $10 for students, children and older people. Saturday night benefit performance: $25 to $100. 9 Livingston Avenue, New Brunswick. (732) 246-7717.
JOHN HARMS CENTER FOR THE ARTS ''Grease.'' Friday at 7:30 p.m.; Saturday at 2 p.m. and 7:30 p.m. Tickets: $12. 30 North Van Brunt Street, Englewood. (201) 567-3600.

HUNTERDON HILLS PLAYHOUSE ''Mary, Mary,'' Jean Kerr's comedy. Through June 30. Monday through Saturday luncheon performances at 11 a.m., $35.50 and $39.50; Saturdays at 6:30 p.m., $43 and $47; Sundays at 3:30 p.m., $41.50 and $45.50. Reservations required. Exit 12 off Routes 78 and 22, Perryville. (800) 447-7313.

MILL HILL PLAYHOUSE ''Blinding Light,'' by William Mastrosimone. Friday through June 25. Wednesdays at 2 p.m.; Thursdays at 5:30 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays at 8 p.m.; Saturday matinees at 3 p.m.; Sunday matinees at 3 p.m. Tickets: $17.50 and $20. Front and Montgomery Streets, Trenton. (609) 392-5589.

MONTCLAIR KIMBERLY ACADEMY Sharron Miller's Academy for the Performing Arts presents ''Raise the Roof,'' a fund-raising performance. Today at 3 p.m. Tickets: $15; $5 for children under 16 and older people. Penick Auditorium, 201 Valley Road, Montclair. (973) 746-8723.

MONTCLAIR STATE UNIVERSITY TheaterFest, the Professional Equity Theatre-in-Residence. Through August. Patti LuPone in ''Matters of the Heart.'' Thursday and Friday at 8 p.m.; Saturday at 8 p.m.; next Sunday at 3 p.m. Tickets: $35 to $45. Valley Road and Normal Avenue, Upper Montclair. (973) 655-5112.

NEW JERSEY PERFORMING ARTS CENTER The West Essex Chapter of the New Jersey State Opera Guild will present ''Tosca'' Operalogue by Giacomo Puccini. Friday at 7:30 p.m. and next Sunday at 3 p.m. Tickets: $10. Prudential Hall. 1 Center Street, Newark. (973) 992-3839 or (888) 466-5722.

NEW JERSEY REPERTORY COMPANY ''Octet,'' Mark Dunn comic-drama. Through June 18. Thursdays through Saturdays at 8 p.m.; Sundays at 2 p.m. Tickets: $25. Opening night on Friday with reception: $35. Lumia Theater, 179 Broadway, Long Branch. (732) 229-3166.

PAPER MILL PLAYHOUSE ''Pippin.'' Wednesday through July 23. Wednesdays through Saturdays at 8 p.m.; Sundays at 7:30 p.m.; Thursday and Sunday matinees at 2 p.m.; Saturday matinees at 2:30 p.m. Tickets: $36 to $60. Brookside Drive, Millburn. (973) 376-4343.

PREMIER THEATER COMPANY ''Carousel.'' Through June 24. Thursdays, Fridays and Saturdays at 8 p.m.; Sunday matinees next Sunday and June 18 at 2 p.m. Tickets: $20; $18 for older people; $15 for students; $12 for children 12 and under. Algonquin Arts Theater, 169 Main Street, Manasquan. (732) 223-7122.

RITZ THEATER Annual New Play Festival. Today at 2 p.m. Tickets: $10. ''Not Necessarily for Kids,'' with Joey Quaile and the Quaile Family. Friday and Saturday at 8 p.m.; next Sunday at 2 p.m. Tickets: $16 for Friday and Saturday; $12.50 for Sunday. 915 White Horse Pike, Oaklyn. (609) 858-5230.
STATE THEATER ''Show Boat.'' Friday at 8 p.m.; Saturday at 3 p.m. and 8 p.m. Tickets: $21 to $47. 15 Livingston Avenue, New Brunswick. (732) 246-7469.

TRI-STATE ACTORS THEATER ''All I Really Need to Know I Learned in Kindergarten,'' a musical based on the books by Robert Fulghum. Through June 18. Fridays and Saturdays at 8 p.m.; Sundays at 3 p.m. Tickets: $15 for Fridays and Saturdays; $13 for Sunday matinees; $11 for students and older people. Garris Center Theater, Broad Street, Branchville. (888) 840-7889.
VILLAGERS THEATER ''West Side Story.'' Through June 24. Fridays and Saturdays at 8 p.m.; Sundays at 2 p.m. Tickets: $15. 475 DeMott Lane, Somerset. (732) 873-2710.

WESTMONT THEATER COMPANY ''Let Them Eat Cake -- A Second Helping,'' performed by New Jersey Gay Men's Chorus. Saturday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $15; $12 for students and older people. 49 Haddon Avenue, Westmont. (609) 396-7774.
MUSIC

CAPE MAY CONVENTION HALL Cape May Music Festival. Through June 25. Mary Wilson and the Supremes and the Cape May Festival Pops Orchestra. Today at 8 p.m. Cape May Festival Orchestra, featuring Robert Theis, pianist. Thursday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $20 for each concert; $10 for older people; $5 for students. Beach Drive and Stockton Street, Cape May. The New York Chamber Ensemble, featuring Joyce Castle, mezzo-soprano, and William Schimmel, accordianist. Tuesday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $15. Episcopal Church of the Advent. Washington and Franklin Streets, Cape Map.(609) 884-5404.

COMMUNITY THEATER OF MORRISTOWN Grover Kemble and Loudon Wainwright. Friday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $22 and $16. (973) 539-8008. Morris Choral Society presents Brahms's ''German Requiem.'' Saturday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $25, $20 and $18. 100 South Street, Morristown. (973) 895-4142.

GRACE EPISCOPAL CHURCH Harmonium Classical Choral Society, with guest, Montville High School Chamber Singers, presents ''Songs of the Earth'' choral program. Today at 7:30 p.m. Tickets: $15; $10 for students and older people. Madison Avenue at Kings Road, Madison. (973) 538-6969.
JOE'S MILL HILL SALOON Andy Keenan, blues and funk. Friday at 9 p.m. Framework. Saturday at 8:30 p.m. Broad and Market Streets, Trenton. (609) 394-7222.

THE MANOR ''Special Tribute to the Music of Les Paul and Mary Ford,'' performance by Bob Harris, guitarist, and Mary Ford, vocalist. Wednesday at 7 p.m. Tickets: $90. 111 Prospect Avenue, West Orange. (973) 731-2369.

NEW JERSEY PERFORMING ARTS CENTER ''An Evening of Music,'' the Carollo Scholarship Recital, scholarship musicians of the Newark Community School of the Arts. For Ages 10 and up. Tuesday at 7 p.m. Tickets: $12; $7 for children under 14. The Chase Room. ''Absolut Sounds of the City 2000,'' outdoor music series. Thursday evenings through Aug. 31. Ogans, Brazilian Candomble music; Kim Lake, jazz; Raphael Cruz, Dominican Latin jazz; and McKnight, soul. Thursday, 5 p.m. to 10 p.m. Theater Square. 1 Center Street, Newark. (888) 466-5722.

OCEAN GROVE SUMMER CONCERT SERIES Through Sept. 9. The Doo Wop! Show, featuring the Marvelettes, Duprees, Del Vikings and Shirely Alston Reeves, original lead singer of the Shirelles. Saturday at 7:30 p.m. Tickets: $25 (reserved); $20 (regular admission). The Great Auditorium, two blocks from the ocean at the intersection of Pilgrim and Ocean Pathways, Ocean Grove. (732) 988-0645.
OPERA AT FLORHAM ''Die Fledermaus.'' Today at 3 p.m. Tickets: $35; $31.50 for older people. Fairleigh Dickinson University, Dreyfuss Theater, Florham-Madison campus, Madison. (973) 443-8620.
PNC BANK ARTS CENTER Don Henley. Friday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $85, $55 and $30. Exit 116, off the Garden State Parkway, Holmdel. (201) 507-8900.

PRINCETON UNIVERSITY RICHARDSON AUDITORIUM The American Boychoir will perform Haydn's ''Missa St. Leopoldi'' and ''Vesperae pro festo Sanctissimae Innocentium.'' Today at 7 p.m. Tickets: $25, $20 and $15; $10 for students. Alexander Hall, Princeton. (609) 258-5000.

SOMERSET COUNTY VOCATIONAL AND TECHNICAL SCHOOL Le Dixieband, part of ''Jazz in Bridgewater'' series. Saturday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $15. Intersection of Routes 22 and 202/206 and Interstate 287, Bridgewater. (908) 526-8900, ext. 7219.
STEVENS INSTITUTE OF TECHNOLOGY Broadside Electric, progressive folk ensemble. Friday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $5. DeBaun Auditorium, Edwin A. Stevens Hall, 5th and Hudson Streets, Hoboken. (201) 216-8937.
WATCHUNG ARTS CENTER Jean Farnsworth, harpist. Friday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $10. Dirdy Birdies Jug Band. Saturday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $10. Watchung Circle, 18 Stirling Road, Watchung. (908) 753-0190.
MUSEUMS AND GALLERIES

AFRICAN ART MUSEUM OF THE S.M.A. FATHERS ''Eloquent Threads: The Language of African Costumes and Textiles.'' Through Dec. 31. Hours: daily, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. 23 Bliss Avenue, Tenafly. (201) 894-8611.

AMERICAN LABOR MUSEUM ''Vital Vestiges,'' a photodocumentary of the Paterson historic district's ruins. ''What is Industrial Hygiene?'' photo and illustration exhibit on loan from the American Industrial Hygiene Association in Virginia. Through June 25. Hours: Wednesdays through Saturdays, 1 to 4 p.m.; other times by appointment. Botto House National Landmark, 83 Norwood Street, Haledon. (973) 595-7953.

ATRIUM ART GALLERY ''Five Views,'' featuring landscape photography. Through July 21. Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. Morris County Administration and Records Building, Morristown. (973) 285-6120.

BRION GALLERIES ''New Work by Oil Painter Cathy Lang.'' Through June 25. ''Alien Beings of Uncertain Origin,'' one-man show of monotypes by Stephen McKenzie. Saturday through Aug. 27. Hours: Wednesdays and Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays, 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. 1293 Route 179, Lambertville. (609) 397-7030.

CHAMOT GALLERY ''The Shape of Things That Are,'' distinctive sculptures by Lawrence Fane and Christopher Whittey. Through July 2. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. 111 First Street, Jersey City. (201) 610-1468.

COOPER GALLERY ''The Illuminated Woman,'' a solo exhibition of paintings and drawings by Eileen Kennedy-Dyne. Through July 1. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, noon to 7 p.m. 295 Grove Street, Jersey City. (201) 451-1074.

DIVIANA ''Whimsy and Magic,'' a gala art show of handcrafted wallhangings by Dutch-born artist, Mariette Van Hees-Theeuwes of Randolph. Through June. Hours: Monday through Friday, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Saturday, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. 1225 Sussex Turnpike, Randolph. (973) 895-2661.

EXTENSION GALLERY Joseph W. Acquah's ''Dream Fulfilled, to God Be the Glory.'' Tomorrow through June 29. Opening reception: Saturday, 4 p.m. to 7 p.m. Hours: Mondays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m.; other times by appointment. 60 Ward Avenue Extension, Mercerville. (609) 890-7777.

GROUNDS FOR SCULPTURE ''Spring Exhibition'' featuring Red Grooms: sculpture; Bill Barrett: sculpture and painting; and Andrzej Pitynski: partisans. Through July 2. Hours: Thursdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m.; Tuesday and Wednesday by appointment. 18 Fairgrounds Road, Hamilton Township. (609) 586-0616.

HUNTERDON MUSEUM OF ART ''Robert Forman: 'Narratives in Thread' and 'Huichol Art in the Collection of Robert Forman.' '' Through June 18. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. 7 Lower Center Street, Clinton. (908) 735-8415.

LIBERTY SCIENCE CENTER ''Lakota Wolf Preserve,'' photographs by Dan Bacon. Through June 18. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 9:30 to 5:30 p.m. Environment Level, Liberty State Park, 251 Phillip Street, Jersey City. (201) 451-0006, extension 295.

MACCULLOCH HALL HISTORICAL MUSEUM Annual Rose Day celebration, featuring opening of new exhibit, ''New Jersey Stoneware as Artful Goods.'' Today, 1 p.m. to 4 p.m. ''Woven Into Words: Coverlets in America.'' Through Aug. 13. Admission: $3; $2 for older people and students. Hours: Wednesdays, Thursdays and Sundays, 1 to 4 p.m. 45 Macculloch Avenue, Morristown. (973) 538-2404.

MONMOUTH MUSEUM ''New Jersey's Pinelands: Water in the Balance.'' Through Sept. 3. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 4:30 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 5 p.m. Admission: $4. 761 Newman Springs Road, Lincroft. (732) 747-2266.

MONTCLAIR ART MUSEUM ''Untamed Spirits: Animal Imagery in Native American Art.'' Through July 30. Will Barnet: A Timeless World. Through Aug. 20. Hours: Tuesdays, Wednesdays, Fridays and Saturdays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Thursdays and Sundays, 1 to 5 p.m. Admission: $5; $4 for older people and students; free for members and children under 12. 3 South Mountain Avenue, Montclair. (973) 746-5555.

MONTCLAIR STATE UNIVERSITY David Cole: Recent Work and In Gathering of Paint Stirrers. Through July 21. Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. University Gallery, Life Hall, Valley Road and Normal Avenue, Upper Montclair. (973) 655-7640.

MORRIS MUSEUM ''The Collected Century, 1900 to 2000.'' Through next Sunday. ''Ice Age,'' featuring casts of mammals from the Pleistocene epoch. Through June 18. Hours: Sundays, 1 to 5 p.m.; Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Thursdays to 8 p.m. Admission: $5; $3 for older people and children under age 3. 6 Normandy Heights Road, Morristown. (973) 538-0454.

NEW JERSEY CENTER FOR VISUAL ARTS ''Forgotten Places,'' recent paintings and digital prints by Liz Demaree. Through Friday. ''On the Horizon: Landscape at the Millennium.'' Through next Sunday. Hours: Monday through Friday, noon to 4 p.m.; Thursday, 7 to 9 p.m.; Saturday and Sunday, 2 to 4 p.m. Palmer Gallery, 68 Elm Street, Summit. (908) 273-9121.

NEW JERSEY HISTORICAL SOCIETY ''History's Mysteries,'' interactive exhibition. Through June. ''Dining In, Dining Out,'' featuring photographs, video clips, rare silverware, period furniture and 18th-century cookbooks. Through summer, 2001. ''Pride of Newark: Baseball's Bears and Eagles,'' about the history of baseball in Newark. Through Summer 2001. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. 52 Park Place, Newark. (973) 596-8500.

NEW JERSEY STATE MUSEUM ''Forgotten Gateway: The Abandoned Building of Ellis Island,'' photographs by Larry Racioppo. Through June 30. ''Building a Collection: Fine Art at the New Jersey State Museum.'' Through Aug. 20. ''Famine Ships: From the Collection of the Irish American Cultural Institute,'' (Fine and Decorative Arts Galleries, 3rd floor). Through July 2. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 9 a.m. to 4:45 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Free. 205 West State Street, Trenton. (609) 292-6464.

NEWARK MUSEUM ''The Art of Ink in American 2000: International Contemporary Calligraphy.'' Through July 9. ''Year of the Dragon: The Calligraphy of Wang Fangyu.'' Through Nov. 12. ''From Tabletop to TV Tray: China and Glass in America, 1880-1980.'' Through June 18. ''Needless Necessity: Jewelry, Silver and Personal Meaning.'' Through December. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, noon to 5 p.m.; Thursdays (after hours) until 8:30 p.m. 49 Washington Street, Newark. (973) 596-6550.

NOYES MUSEUM OF ART Inspired by Nature series, featuring ''Recreating Flowers: The Glass Wonders of Paul J. Stankard.'' Through Sept. 3 ''Capturing the Jersey Shore: Works of Anthony J. Rudisill.'' Through Sept. 10. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. Admission: $3; $2 for older people and students. Lily Lake Road, Oceanville. (609) 652-8848.

PRINCETON UNIVERSITY ART MUSEUM ''Curator's Choice: Recent Acquisitions.'' Through Tuesday. Photographs by Barbara Bosworth. Through June 18. ''A Window Into Collecting American Folk Art: The Edward Duff Balken Collection.'' Through June 18. ''Flora and Fauna in Chinese Painting.'' Through July 30. Yayoi Kusama: Early Drawings From the Collection of Richard Castellane. Through July 30. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 5 p.m. Princeton campus. (609) 258-3788.

PUFFIN CULTURAL FORUM ''Terra Infirma: Art, Activisim and the Environment.'' Through June 24. Hours: Wednesday through Saturday, 1 to 5 p.m.; or by appointment. 20 East Oakdene Avenue, Teaneck. (201) 836-8923.

RUTGERS UNIVERSITY - CAMDEN ''Spirit of the Mask'' exhibit. Tuesday through July 29. Hours: Mondays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. Stedman Gallery, Third Street between Cooper Street and Benjamin Franklin Bridge, Camden. (856) 225-6350.

RUTGERS UNIVERSITY - NEWARK Prints and Drawings by Anaida Hernandez, 1989-1999. Through Sept. Dana Library, 185 University Avenue, Newark. (973) 353-5900. ''Art of Ink 2000,'' exhibit in conjunction with The Newark Museum. Through July 16. Robeson Center Art Gallery, 350 Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Boulevard, Newark. (973) 353-5119, ext. 32.

SIMON GALLERY Anne Raymond and Alice Zinnes, paintings. Through June 24. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, noon to 6 p.m.; Saturdays, noon to 5 p.m.; other times by appointment. 48 Bank Street, Morristown. (973) 538-5456.

SPRINGFIELD PUBLIC LIBRARY ''The Jersey Shore in 2-D and 3-D.'' Through July 13. Hours: Mondays, Wednesdays and Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 8:30 p.m.; Tuesdays, Fridays and Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 4:30 p.m.; Sundays, 1 p.m. to 3:30 p.m. Donald B. Palmer Museum, 66 Mountain Avenue, Springfield. (973) 376-4930.

SWAIN GALLERIES ''Fruit, Florals and Flourishes.'' Through June 30. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Saturdays, 9:30 a.m. to 4 p.m. 703 Watchung Avenue, Plainfield. (908) 756-1707.

WHEATON VILLAGE ''American Glass: 1900-2000,'' featuring more than 100 industrial and decorative pieces. Through Oct. 22. ''2000 Flowers.'' Through next Sunday. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $7; $6 for older people; $3.50 for students. Exit 26, Route 55, Millville. (800) 998-4552, extension 2756.

YOGI BERRA MUSEUM Warner Wolf will sign copies of his new book, ''Let's Go to the Videotape! All the Players and Replays -- Of My Life in Sports.'' Tomorrow, 4 p.m. to 6 p.m. ''Glove Story,'' interactive exhibit on the evolution of the baseball glove, including 19th century rare vintage models and hands-on replicas. Through June 26. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Tickets: $4; $2 for children. Montclair State University, 8 Quarry Road, Little Falls. (973) 655-2377.
FOR CHILDREN

BARNES & NOBLE Open Mic Poetry for Kids!, Cheryl Racanelli, host and creator of the Poetry Jar Workshop for Children. Wednesday at 7 p.m. For children in kindergarten through grade eight. Free. 1180 Raritan Road, Clark. (732) 574-1818.
COUNT BASIE THEATER Madcap Mutts. Saturday at 2 p.m. Tickets: $15 for children; $20 for adults. 99 Monmouth Street, Red Bank. (732) 842-9000.

FORUM THEATER COMPANY ''Narnia; the Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe,'' based on the ''Chronicles of Narnia'' by C. S. Lewis. Thursday at 10 a.m.; Saturday at 11 a.m. Tickets: $9. 314 Main Street, Metuchen. (732) 548-0582.

HUNTERDON MUSEUM OF ART ''Spring Fever,'' workshops and classes for children and adults, including KinderArt, Cartooning Around, Collage Kids and more. Through Thursday. 7 Lower Center Street, Clinton. (908) 735-8415.

NEWARK MUSEUM ''Where in the Universe Is Carmen Sandiego?'' at the Alice and Leonard Dreyfuss Planetarium. Through October. Saturdays and Sundays, 1 p.m. and 3 p.m. Tickets: $3; $2 for members; $1 for children and older people. 49 Washington Street, Newark. (973) 596-6355.

NEW JERSEY STATE MUSEUM ''Laser Millennium 3-D,'' planetarium laser light show. Saturdays and Sundays at 1 and 3 p.m. Through June 25. Tickets: $6 includes 3-D glasses. 205 West State Street, Trenton. (609) 292-6464.
PEQUEST TROUT HATCHERY AND NATURAL RESOURCE EDUCATION CENTER ''Amphibian Amble.'' Saturday at 1 p.m. Registration is required. Route 46 (nine miles west of Hackettstown), Oxford. (908) 637-4125.

STONY BROOK-MILLSTONE WATERSHED ''Busy Bees,'' program for preschool children, ages 3 to 5. Friday, 10 a.m. to 11:30 a.m. Pre-registration is required. Fee: $12. Kate Gorrie Butterfly House Grand Opening. Saturday, 1 p.m. to 4 p.m. Free. Buttinger Nature Center, 31 Titus Mill Road, Pennington. (609) 737-7592.

TRAILSIDE NATURE AND SCIENCE CENTER Planetarium Show. Today, 2 p.m. and 3:30 p.m. Admission: $3; $2.55 for older people. ''Frogs by Flashlight.'' Wednesday, 7 p.m. to 8 p.m. Pre-registration is required. 452 New Providence Road, Mountainside. (908) 789-3670.
SPOKEN WORD

BARNES & NOBLE Chris Komisarjevsky, father of six and president and CEO of Burson-Marsteller, will discuss and sign his book ''Peanut Butter and Jelly Management: Tales From Parenthood, Lessons for Managers.'' Tuesday at 7:30 p.m. Free. 3981 Highway 9, Freehold. (732) 409-2929.

BENNETT BOOK NOOK Al Roker will discuss and sign his book ''Don't Make Me Stop This Car!,'' an autobiographical book on parenting. Saturday, 2 p.m. to 4 p.m. Wykoff Square Plaza, 303 Franklin Avenue, Wyckoff. (201) 891-8444.

BOOKENDS BOOKSTORE Jane Heller, author of ''Name Dropping,'' will discuss and sign her book. Today at 1 p.m. Dr. Phil Lee, golf psychiatrist, will discuss and sign his book, ''Shrink Your Handicap.'' Saturday at 1 p.m. 232 East Ridgewood Avenue, Ridgewood. (201) 445-0726.

ENGLEWOOD PUBLIC LIBRARY Dianne Golder, travel expert, will present a slide show and lecture, titled ''What's New in the Big Apple.'' Tomorrow at 7:30 p.m. O'Brien Boldt will discuss the topic, ''Health Care for All/NJ.'' Wednesday at 8 p.m. Tor Hansen, Cape Cod artist-naturalist, will present a slide show and lecture, titled ''Butterfly Gardening.'' Thursday at 7:30 p.m. Free. 31 Engle Street, Englewood. (201) 568-2215.

RECTO VERSO BOOK STORE Jabari Jones and Maria Mazziotti Gillan present ''Poetry of Political Change'' Reading Series. Thursday, 7:30 p.m. to 10 p.m. Free. 90 Albany Street, New Brunswick. (732) 247-2324.
ETC.
MONTCLAIR STATE UNIVERSITY ArtsFest 2000, featuring Brazil 500 painting exhibition. Through July 21. Art Gallery, Life Hall. Valley Road and Normal Avenue, Upper Montclair. (973) 655-4452.

NEW JERSEY INTERNATIONAL FILM FESTIVAL SUMMER 2000 ''The Life and Times of Hank Greenberg,'' the 1999 documentary about the Jewish baseball hero from the Bronx. Today at 7 p.m. Aviva Kempner, producer and director of the documentary, will discuss the film today. Scott Hall, 123. Rutgers University, College Avenue and Hamilton Street, New Brunswick. ''F for Fake.'' Thursday at 7 p.m. Loree Hall, 24. Rutgers University, Nichol Avenue and George Street, Douglass College Campus, New Brunswick. ''Titus.'' Friday through next Sunday at 7 p.m. Friday and Saturday in Scott Hall, 123; next Sunday, Loree Hall, 24. Tickets: $5; $4 for members. (732) 932-8482.

NEW JERSEY SEAFOOD FESTIVAL 36 of the state's finest seafood restaurants, more than 60 artists and crafters, jazz and blues performances and more. Saturday and next Sunday, 11 a.m to 7 p.m. Free admission. Belmar Oceanfront at Silver Lake Park, Ocean Avenue and 5th Avenue, Belmar. (732) 774-8506.

OMNIPOINT NEW JERSEY FRESH SEAFOOD FESTIVAL Aquariums, touch tanks and other exhibits, as well as rides music and boat rides. Saturday and next Sunday, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m. Admission: $3; $2 for children. Historic Gardner's Basin, New Hampshire Avenue, Atlantic City. (609) 347-4386.

RIVERFEST 2000 Food and Jazz Festival, presented by Riverview Medical Center and organized by the Eastern Monmouth Area Chamber of Commerce. Today, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Free. Take the Garden State Parkway to Exit 109, then Newman Springs Road (Route 520 East) to its end. Turn left (north) on Broad Street. Marine Park, Red Bank. (888) 438-3378.
SAINT ANTHONY STREET FESTIVAL Games, rides, raffles and entertainment. Thursday through next Sunday. St. Francis Church, 3rd and Jefferson Streets, Hoboken. (201) 659-1772 or 1776.

SPRING LAKE HISTORICAL SOCIETY Annual House Tour, including seven homes, two inns, a historic church and the Historical Society's museum. Thursday, 10 a.m. to 3 p.m. Tour tickets: $20. Luncheon tickets are an additional $20. Tour begins at Ocean House, 102 Sussex Avenue, Spring Lake. (732) 449-2477 or 9341.
TWO RIVERS ANTIQUES SHOW AND GARDEN TOUR Antiques Show, today, 11:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. Tickets: $10. Rumson Country Day School, 35 Bellevue Avenue, Rumson. (732) 923-6886.

WEIS ECOLOGY CENTER Black Mountain to Boston Mine Hike. Today, 9:30 a.m. to 3 p.m. Fee: $5. ''Birds and Botany of High Mountain Park Preserve'' interpretive hike. Saturday, 9 a.m. to noon. Fee: $6. ''Family Day at Sandy Hook Bay.'' Saturday, 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. Fee: $7. Pre-registration required. 150 Snake Den Road, Ringwood. (973) 835-2160.
At the Casinos
All tickets are available through Ticketmaster, (800) 736-1420.

BALLY'S PARK PLACE ''Legends in Concert,'' impersonations of Stevie Wonder, Little Richard, Elvis Presley, Linda Ronstadt and Barbara Streisand. Mondays through Thursdays at 3:30 and 7:30 p.m.; Saturdays at 8 and 10:30 p.m.; Sundays at 7:30 and 10 p.m. Tickets: $15 to $25. Park Cabaret, Boardwalk and Park Place. (800) 225-5977.

CLARIDGE HOTEL ''Dream, Dream, Dream,'' featuring songs by the Everly Brothers. Through June 17. Monday through Thursday at 8 p.m.; Saturday at 7:30 p.m. and 10 p.m.; Sunday at 7 p.m. Tickets: $15, Sunday through Thursday; $19, Saturday. Palace Theater, Boardwalk and Park Place. (609) 340-3700.
RESORTS CASINO HOTEL China Guandong Cantonese Opera Troupe II. Today at 1 a.m. Tickets: $15, $25 and $35. 1133 Boardwalk. (888) 771-1786.

TROPICANA Engelbert Humperdinck with special guest, Louise Dorsey. Friday at 9 p.m.; Saturday at 8 p.m.; next Sunday at 7 p.m. Tickets: $25 to $50. ''Latin Fever.'' Through June 17. Mondays, Tuesdays and Thursdays at 8 p.m.; Wednesdays at 3:30 and 7:30 p.m.; Fridays at 9 p.m.; Saturdays at 8 and 11:30 p.m.; Sundays at 7 p.m. Tickets: $9.90. Boardwalk and Brighton Avenue. (609) 340-4020.
TRUMP MARINA Diana Krall. Friday at 10 p.m.; Saturday at 9 p.m. Tickets: $50. The Shell. Huron Avenue and Brigantine Boulevard. (800) 777-8477.
TRUMP TAJ MAHAL Kool and the Gang and the Boogie Wonder Band. Saturday at 11 p.m. Free. The Casbah Night Club. 1000 Boardwalk, at Virginia Avenue. (609) 449-1000.
